title: Neuropathic pain
summary: Neuropathic pain is pain caused by damage or disease affecting the somatosensory nervous system.[1][2] Neuropathic pain may be associated with abnormal sensations called dysesthesia or pain from normally non-painful stimuli (allodynia). It may have continuous and/or episodic (paroxysmal) components. The latter resemble stabbings or electric shocks. Common qualities include burning or coldness, "pins and needles" sensations, numbness and itching.[2]
